channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Gold Bars, Moldy Cash and a Chinese Official’s Mother Who Can Explain It All
item.description: Anticorruption investigators say they found in a family home some 120 million renminbi in cash, 37 kilograms of gold bars and ownership documents for 68 homes, including seven in expensive parts of Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: North Korea to Send Senior Envoy to Russia
item.description: The announcement came as Pyongyang sought to improve its ties with Russia as a possible counterbalance to China.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Edward J. Ramotowski on Implications of the New U.S.-China Visa Policy
item.description: The State Department official discusses how the new visa policy came about, what remains to be done and where the United States stands to benefit.
item.dc:creator: By JESS MACY YU
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry issued one of the first 10-year visas to a Chinese applicant, Yang Bo, at the United States Embassy in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: Lyon Journal: Brushing Off a French Stigma That Doggie Bags Are for Beggars
item.description: Authorities in Lyon, France, are promoting doggie bags in local restaurants to curb food waste, but are facing the idea that it is a sign of poverty.
item.dc:creator: By AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:credit: Marlene Awaad for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yoann Blanc, owner and chef of La Tête de Lard, a typical “bouchon” Lyonnais restaurant, showed off his form of a doggie bag.

item.title: Sudan and Rebels Under Pressure to Find Path to Peace
item.description: Talks that began Wednesday are seen as part of a comprehensive national dialogue that includes finding a way to greater political freedom.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: Nowhere to Run in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: A cease-fire has been in effect in the rebel areas of eastern Ukraine since September, but severe depopulation is a clear sign that war is once again looming.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A boy in Ilovaisk, Ukraine, next to his house, which was destroyed in a Russian offensive this summer. A cease-fire on Sept. 5 has done little to curb the violence.

item.title: U.N. Commission Presses U.S. on Torture
item.description: A United Nations panel that monitors compliance with an antitorture treaty expressed skepticism Thursday about American law enforcement and national security practices.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Iraq and Kurds Reach Deal on Oil Exports and Budget Payments
item.description: A standoff began earlier this year when Kurdish officials angered Baghdad by exporting oil produced in their region directly to Turkey and not through the Iraqi Oil Ministry.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gas burn-off and oil tanks at the northern oil fields in Kirkuk, Iraq. Kurdish officials angered Baghdad by exporting oil produced in their region directly to Turkey.

item.title: Comet Landing Bumpier Than Initially Thought
item.description: The European Space Agency lander is sitting in a skewed position on the comet’s surface, compromising some aspects of the $1.75 billion Rosetta mission.
item.dc:creator: By KENNETH CHANG
item.media:description: A two-image panorama taken by the Philae lander from the surface of Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.

item.title: Kerry Is Optimistic After Meeting Over Holy Site in Jerusalem
item.description: John Kerry met with the leaders of Jordan, Israel and the Palestinian Authority to discuss the site known to Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary and to Jews as Temple Mount.
item.dc:creator: By RANA F. SWEIS and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: After an Attack on U.S. Sailors, 12 Suspects Are Charged and Released
item.description: Twelve Turks arrested in Istanbul in connection with a videotaped assault on three visiting American sailors were charged on Thursday with insult, inflicting injury and violating Turkey’s protest and rally law, but all of them were released, Turkey’s Anadolu news agency reported.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: New Recall by Honda After Death in Malaysia Is Tied to Takata Airbag
item.description: The fatality is the first outside the United States to be linked to defective airbags made by Takata.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: A Tokyo billboard for Takata Corporation. Takata airbag defects have been linked to five deaths.

item.title: World Briefing: Bosnia: 11 Accused of Assisting Militants
item.description: The police on Thursday arrested 11 people accused of fighting alongside Islamist militants in Syria and Iraq or recruiting and raising money for such groups.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: France: Militant Jailed Over Syria Link
item.description: A Frenchman was sentenced to seven years in prison on Thursday for having joined an Islamist group in Syria, the first such ruling in France.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Portugal: Legionnaires’ Disease Alert
item.description: An outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease has killed at least five people and sickened more than 300 in Portugal, the World Health Organization reported Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Psychologists to Review Role in Detainee Interrogations
item.description: The nation’s largest organization of psychologists will investigate whether it supported the government’s use of torture in the interrogation of prisoners during the Bush administration.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES RISEN

item.title: Top U.S. General Says He’s Open to Using Ground Troops to Retake Mosul
item.description: President Obama’s top military adviser said he would consider deploying a limited number of American forces to fight alongside Iraqi troops moving to retake areas held by militants.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER, DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: In Ebola Outbreak in Liberia, a Family’s Strength Can Be Its Fatal Flaw
item.description: The Doryen family, unbowed survivors of Liberia’s civil war, saw seven members die from the virus in a matter of months and lost its sense of unity.
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: Kaizer Dour, 22, in his Facebook profile photo.

item.title: Warner and Tencent Announce Licensing Deal
item.description: Warner will grant Tencent, the Chinese Internet company, licenses to use its music through Tencent’s various outlets online.
item.category: International Federation of the Phonographic Industry
item.dc:creator: By BEN SISARIO

item.title: Tuning Out Colleague’s Protests, Judge Clears FIFA World Cup Bidding
item.description: The head judge of FIFA’s ethics committee said an investigation of the bidding for the 2018 and 2022 World Cups found potential ethics violations but said the voting’s integrity was intact. The conclusions were immediately contested.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Hans-Joachim Eckert, right, who heads the adjudicatory arm of FIFA’s ethics committee, released his 42-page summary after reviewing the work of Michael J. Garcia, left, the head of the investigatory chamber of the committee.

item.title: Afghan Leaders Miss Goal for Choosing Cabinet
item.description: President Ashraf Ghani had promised to have a cabinet in place within 45 days of his inauguration in a coalition with his rival, Abdullah Abdullah.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Post-Mortems of Victims Point to Tainted Medication in India Sterilization Deaths
item.description: Autopsies of women who died at a government sterilization camp suggest that “spurious medicines” were to blame, not unsanitary conditions or rushed surgery, a medical official said.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: A funeral in the eastern Indian state of Chhattisgarh for a women who died after undergoing sterilization at a government camp.

item.title: For Romanians, Presidential Election Hinges on Issue of Trust
item.description: Voters must decide which of the two candidates can best be trusted to continue an open and strong democracy in Romania and avoid the dictatorlike tactics used by the president of neighboring Hungary.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN and KIT GILLET
item.media:description: Victor Ponta, center, with his wife, and Klaus Johannis before a presidential debate on Wednesday in Bucharest, Romania.

item.title: Samantha Power, U.S. Ambassador, Issues Warning on Anti-Semitism in Europe
item.description: The ambassador, a top aide to President Obama, made her comments against the backdrop of rising anti-Semitic attacks in Europe,
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: ISIS Chief Emerges, Urging ‘Volcanoes of Jihad’
item.description: Countering rumors that he was dead, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the Islamic State leader, issued a new call to arms in an audio clip posted online.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and RICK GLADSTONE
